node.title: Austria man kept dead mother in cellar, police say
node.description: The suspect is said to have "mummified" the corpse in order to continue receiving her pension.

node.title: 'I'll be at front of queue to change my slave name'
node.description: Descendants of African slaves welcome a Dutch city's decision to scrap fees for changing names.

node.title: Behind China's crackdown on K-pop and fan clubs
node.description: Chinese authorities have made it clear that they are not tolerant of overzealous celebrity fans.

node.title: First refugees arrive in Wales after Taliban coup
node.description: Those arriving in the country have directly supported Welsh-based armed forces in Afghanistan.

node.title: Upside-down rhino research wins Ig Nobel Prize
node.description: Who knew? It's actually safer to move a tranquilised rhino by its ankles than on its side or chest.

node.title: Biden requires vaccines for millions of US workers
node.description: President Biden is using his executive power to require that big companies vaccinate employees.

node.title: Biden administration challenges Texas abortion law
node.description: The Texas law effectively bans abortions from as early as six weeks into a pregnancy.

node.title: Hong Kong police raid Tiananmen Square museum
node.description: The raid comes a day after four members of the group that ran the venue were arrested.

node.title: Gardaí continue investigation into Kerry deaths
node.description: The bodies of three members of the same family were found on Tuesday.

node.title: Police worker arrested after fatal Cyprus crash
node.description: Christopher Browning was arrested following an accident near Esentepe, north Cyprus.

node.title: Inspirational Afghan robotics team begin 'new chapter'
node.description: The BBC speaks to the women's robotics team about their ordeal trying to leave Afghanistan.

node.title: Corruption a national embarrassment - Kenyan judge
node.description: Chief Justice Martha Koome speaks out

node.title: Top US court halts Texas execution over religion
node.description: The inmate, convicted of murder, is calling for the right to have a pastor's hands on him as he dies.

node.title: Free football tickets for jabbed South Africans
node.description: The government is concerned about growing anti-vaccine sentiment in the country.

node.title: Three held over Florida collapse victim ID thefts
node.description: The suspects are said to have purchased luxury items on illegally obtained credit cards.

node.title: Ford is latest firm to stop making cars in India
node.description: The firm has run up losses of more than $2bn in India and demand for new vehicles has weakened.

node.title: Afghan journalists tell of beatings by Taliban
node.description: Photos circulating online show journalists with welts and bruises after being released from detention.

node.title: Nicaragua orders arrest of award-winning novelist
node.description: State prosecutors accuse Sergio Ramírez of inciting hatred and conspiring to destabilise Nicaragua.

node.title: German football star on trial over assault charge
node.description: Jerome Boateng is accused of injuring his ex-girlfriend during a dispute on holiday in 2018.

node.title: Afghan protesters defy Taliban intimidation
node.description: Demonstrators are on the streets again as pictures emerge showing injuries inflicted on journalists.

node.title: Smoke alarms go off on International Space Station
node.description: The alarm went off as the space station's batteries were being charged, Russia's space agency says.

node.title: Fans rejoice as MS Dhoni returns to team India
node.description: News of cricketer MS Dhoni's return as mentor to team India has sparked celebrations on Twitter.

node.title: North Koreans put hazmat suits on for parade
node.description: Their inclusion may be a sign that a special force was created to prevent the spread of Covid-19.

node.title: Ex-Afghan President Ghani apologises for fleeing
node.description: Ashraf Ghani, who has sought refuge in the UAE, says he left Kabul to avoid "horrific" violence.

node.title: Sydney reveals plan to end months-long lockdown
node.description: Australia's biggest city is likely to exit lockdown from next month, provided vaccinations continue.

node.title: China offers $31m in emergency aid to Afghanistan
node.description: Taliban officials had earlier described China as Afghanistan's most important partner.

node.title: UK to lose spot in Germany's top trading partners
node.description: Customs rules take their toll as German companies swap UK suppliers for alternatives in the EU.

node.title: Patel authorises turning back of migrant boats
node.description: It comes after the home secretary and and France failed to agree on new measures to stop crossings.

node.title: Fire at Covid hospital kills 10 in North Macedonia
node.description: Footage shows a building in flames and clouds of black smoke billowing into the air in the city of Tetovo.

node.title: The Kenyans who are helping the world to cheat
node.description: Some Kenyans try to escape poverty by helping foreign students to fake their academic work.

node.title: 'Pain is a sharp knife, which dulls over time'
node.description: Jupiter Yambem from India died in the 9/11 attacks. His widow learned she could not live with hate.

node.title: UK 'cut climate pledges' for Australia trade deal
node.description: Government ministers agreed to cut climate commitments to clinch the deal it has emerged.

node.title: Theranos founder 'lied and cheated' trial hears
node.description: Elizabeth Holmes misled that blood testing devices worked, prosecutors say, as fraud trial begins.

node.title: 'I'll keep protesting until the Taliban kill me'
node.description: Women in Afghanistan demanding their rights say they have been beaten by the Taliban.

node.title: A new order begins under Taliban rule
node.description: The Taliban's new ministers have taken office - but are they any different this time around?

node.title: Philippines' Duterte to stand as vice-president
node.description: Rivals accuse the president, barred from a second term, of seeking to cling on to power.

node.title: Rebels blamed for mass graves found in Ethiopia
node.description: The bodies of some 119 civilians are found by local officials - rebel forces deny responsibility.

node.title: Could Pakistan be using drones in Afghanistan?
node.description: There are claims that Pakistan has used drones against anti-Taliban forces in Afghanistan.

node.title: Israel makes arrests over Palestinian prison break
node.description: Several relatives of the six inmates who escaped Gilboa prison are reportedly taken into custody.

node.title: Afghan women protest against all-male government
node.description: Dozens of women march in Kabul and in Badakhshan province, angry at the new Taliban government.

node.title: Passengers missing after boats collide in India
node.description: Some 100 people are aboard the boats when they crash on a river in Assam, with one capsizing.

node.title: Guinea coup leaders free political prisoners
node.description: The releases come as West African leaders meet to discuss whether to impose sanctions.

node.title: Guinea country profile
node.description: Provides an overview, basic information and key events for this west African country.

node.title: Email company under fire over police data handover
node.description: The encrypted-email service has just recruited web founder Sir Tim Berners-Lee.

node.title: Denmark tells some migrants to work for benefits
node.description: The prime minister says the new rules are aimed at women from non-Western backgrounds.

node.title: Russian emergencies minister dies on Arctic drill
node.description: Emergencies Minister Yevgeny Zinichev was killed while trying to save a cameraman's life, reports say.

node.title: Spanish bishop quit for love for erotic writer
node.description: Xavier Novell was a traditional and controversial bishop who resigned for "personal reasons".

node.title: Ai Weiwei: Credit Suisse closed account over China
node.description: The Chinese artist says Credit Suisse closed his foundation's bank account over his "criminal record".

node.title: India paves the way for more women in armed forces
node.description: The government says women can join military colleges and be eligible for permanent commissions.

node.title: France to open historic trial over Paris attacks
node.description: Twenty men are going on trial in Paris accused of involvement in France's worst post-WWII atrocity.

node.title: Migrants continue to arrive ahead of France talks
node.description: The home secretary is due to discuss the number of small boat crossings with her French counterpart.

node.title: Bodies of three people with gunshot wounds found
node.description: Gardaí (Irish police) say the bodies were discovered at property in north County Kerry.

node.title: Powerful earthquake hits Mexican coast
node.description: The magnitude-seven quake was felt strongly around 370 km away in Mexico City.

node.title: El Salvador protests as bitcoin crashes on day one
node.description: Angry protests and technological glitches plagued the first day of El Salvador adopting bitcoin.

node.title: Australia media ruled liable for Facebook comments
node.description: A landmark court ruling finds publishers can be sued for comments posted on their social media.

node.title: US 'concerned' by new Afghan Taliban government
node.description: The all-male hard-line cabinet has figures linked to attacks on US troops and blacklisted by the UN.

node.title: Priti Patel to meet French minister over crossings
node.description: The home secretary has warned she could withhold a £54m payment to France unless more boats are stopped.

node.title: Fire at Indonesian jail kills at least 41
node.description: The blaze happened in the early hours of Wednesday when most of the prisoners were asleep.

node.title: Hong Kong Tiananmen vigil organisers arrested
node.description: Members of a pro-democracy organisation have been detained under a controversial security law.

node.title: Flooding hits Mexico hospital, killing 17 patients
node.description: A river bursts its banks in the town of Tula, cutting power and oxygen at the facility, officials say.

node.title: Somali feminist: Facebook being used to censor me
node.description: Hanna Paranta has faced assassination attempts and now online attacks for helping abused women.

node.title: Britney Spears' father files to end conservatorship
node.description: Jamie Spears filed papers in an LA court to formally end the 13-year arrangement with the singer.

node.title: Historic day of reckoning for night of Paris terror
node.description: Survivors and families attend the long-awaited trial of 20 men accused of the deadly 2015 attacks.

node.title: Mexico decriminalises abortion
node.description: A ruling by the supreme courts makes it illegal for women to be prosecuted for having an abortion.

node.title: Chinese social media site suspends K-pop accounts
node.description: The social media site says 22 fan accounts have been suspended for "irrational celebrity support”.

node.title: Dentist fears for Afghan family living in hiding
node.description: Suleyman Sakha says his in-laws, who worked for a humanitarian organisation, are living in dread.

node.title: Spanish woman sues over birth swap error
node.description: Health authorities admit the woman was mistakenly switched with another baby at a hospital in 2002.

node.title: Brazil on edge as Bolsonaro supporters rally
node.description: Police are guarding the Supreme Court amid warnings that the president's supporters may try to storm it.

node.title: Taliban announce new government for Afghanistan
node.description: After naming its cabinet ministers, the group declares that Afghanistan is now an "Islamic emirate".

node.title: Egypt accused of extrajudicial executions cover-up
node.description: Security forces have falsely claimed that suspects are dying in shoot-outs, Human Rights Watch says.

node.title: Ireland to ban the sale of polluting solid fuels
node.description: The new rules, which will make Ireland a low-smoke zone, are expected to be in place within a year.

node.title: Audio of 'talking' Australian duck rediscovered
node.description: The 1987 recording appears to show Ripper the Australian musk duck saying: "You bloody fool".

node.title: About 150 starve to death in Ethiopia - rebels
node.description: There is a "complete depletion of food stocks" in the northern Ethiopian region, the TPLF says.

node.title: Merkel attacks left as polls point to vote defeat
node.description: The German chancellor targets the centre-left favourite to succeed her, ahead of September elections.

node.title: Row over sex offender appearing on Indonesian TV
node.description: A petition asking to keep Saipul Jamil off TV screens has been signed by nearly 500,000 people.

node.title: Poland imposes state of emergency on Belarus border
node.description: The government says it needs to curb a steep rise in illegal migrant crossings from Belarus.

node.title: Are military takeovers on the rise in Africa?
node.description: Despite a series of coups in Africa over the past few months, the longer trend down is downward.

node.title: Al-Qaeda, the Taliban and the binding pledge
node.description: The history of the complex relationship between the two groups.

node.title: Guinea opposition leader backs coup against Condé
node.description: Cellou Dalein Diallo says Sunday's takeover "completes" the work that opposition groups had begun.

node.title: Takeover of UK graphene firm faces security review
node.description: The UK's business secretary intervenes in a takeover of Perpetuus over security concerns.

node.title: Taliban fire warning shots at protesters in Kabul
node.description: Protests grow as more Afghans demand women's rights and chant anti-Taliban and anti-Pakistan slogans.

node.title: More migrants cross English Channel
node.description: Weather conditions have become more favourable for those making the journey.

node.title: El Salvador accepts Bitcoin as legal tender
node.description: Millions of Salvadorians are expected to download a digital wallet app with $30 of free Bitcoin.

node.title: Thousands protest against new farm laws in India
node.description: Security is tight in Haryana state as farmers gather to protest against new agriculture laws.

node.title: Vietnamese man jailed for spreading coronavirus
node.description: Le Van Tri was found guilty of spreading the virus to eight people, one of whom eventually died.

node.title: Kathmandu Holdings expects profit fall
node.description: Outdoor clothing and equipment retailer Kathmandu Holdings' profits have been significantly hit by the recent round of Covid lockdowns in New Zealand and Australia.

node.title: Some still without homes on first Napier flood anniversary
node.description: A year ago today, a weather bomb ripped through Napier. Council data shows 589 properties were damaged, with 115 left uninhabitable and 173 people having to evacuate from their home.

node.title: Justin Trudeau hit by stones on campaign trail
node.description: The Canadian leader's campaign has been disrupted by protesters angry at a planned vaccine mandate.

node.title: Covid-19 positive Aucklander isolating in caravan feels 'scared', abandoned by authorities
node.description: When health authorities asked if she would like to go into MIQ, she said she declined because she did not know much about it and did not want to leave her family without support.

node.title: China court drops Alibaba sexual assault case
node.description: The court said the "forcible indecency" committed by the man was not a crime.

node.title: Australia PM defends Father's Day trip in lockdown
node.description: Scott Morrison is accused of "appalling judgment" for flying to Sydney while millions must stay home.

node.title: Minor girls paraded naked in India 'rain ritual'
node.description: Six girls, some as young as five, were paraded naked as part of a village ritual to summon rainfall.

node.title: Texas abortion clinics 'will be protected'
node.description: The US Justice Department pledge comes after a near-total ban on abortions took effect in the state.

node.title: Myanmar military releases firebrand Buddhist monk
node.description: Wirathu, dubbed the "Buddhist Bin Laden", is known for his anti-Muslim and pro-military views

node.title: Jewellery ad starring trans model wins hearts
node.description: The ad is being praised in India where popular culture still portrays transgender people as caricatures.

node.title: Bolsonaro signs bill to limit power of tech giants
node.description: The president signs a decree aimed at requiring firms to provide "just cause" before removing posts.

node.title: The Wire star Michael K Williams found dead
node.description: The 54-year-old died from a suspected drug overdose in his New York flat, media reports say.

node.title: PM pledges not to abandon Afghan allies left behind
node.description: Boris Johnson promises help for them to leave safely - but is accused of not showing leadership.

node.title: Relatives of MH17 victims speak of trauma in court
node.description: The Malaysian Airlines flight was downed over Ukraine in 2014, killing all 298 people on board.

node.title: Taliban raise flag over resistance stronghold
node.description: The Taliban raise their flag over Panjshir Valley, but resistance fighters deny being defeated.
